ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned different lab techniques like PCR, extracting/purifying RNA, hybridizing RNA, ddPCR, etc.
By taking this course, I reinforced my wet lab skills. I also learned how to keep a lab journal.
Hands on experience with key molecular biology techniques such as cell culture, PCR, transfection, transformation, and etc.

We learned many experimental techniques that would be involved with cloning experiments: primer designs, PCR, transformations, RNA synthesis, nucleic acid isolation techniques, ddPCR, and many more. This class would be great for anyone who has little research experience with respect to wet labs.

I learned valuable skills with regards to various nucleic acid techniques (i.e. RNA extraction, ddPCR). I also learned a lot of the fundamentals of WHY we choose to use certain polymerases, and solutions in experimentation.
Pipetting, PCR

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: pretty chill class, not much work outside of class (short weekly psets that you can work on during class and a final paper), prof explains science/reasoning behind lab techniques pretty in depth
Weaknesses: somewhat disorganized, uncertain schedule, not the most efficient use of time, we fell kind of far behind which made it difficult to write the final manuscript

Strengths: Professor Nelson! He is so kind and seems to really care about this class. Because our experiments would occasionally fail, Prof Nelson would repeat all of them for us to make sure we dont fall too behind. This class is relatively low workload, which really helps you be more engaged with the actual content.

Weaknesses: The class was a little disorganized at times, leaving a lot of us confused on what we were supposed to do. The final paper was also a bit too long (at least 8 pg single spaced) considering how some of our experiments failed and we had to cut our projects short.

This class is excellent for learning new techniques and the science behind them. However, this class is incredibly messy and disorganized. Procedures are changed at the last minute and it seems like there's minimal structure to the class.

I liked how the course was designed as a research project. However, this also means that if something goes wrong, like it often does in research, you are not always able to complete everything you would like.

strengths: I greatly enjoyed the overall course and found it really interesting to learn the background biology and information about why experimental protocols actually work in achieving our x goal. 

weakness: The class was a little bit disorganized at times, although that is sometimes how research goes when experiments don't quite work out.

The course changes every time that it is run based on what the lab we are partnered with wants! However, that also brings up the issue that at times the course could feel a bit disorganized, and it was hard to find certain things on Canvas. It was also hard to gauge how well I was doing in the course because a hefty portion of the grading was done last minute.
You learn a lot about the processes of what you do in lab like PCR, gels, vectors, bacterial transformation.
lacks structure, assignments are just given randomly, and the grading expectations are not clear

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Probably one of the more chill MCDB lab classes you can take, and Prof. Nelson is amazing!

I would only recommend this course to a student who already has basic lab skills and still needs to take 2 lab courses for the MCDB major. The class can be confusing if you are learning these techniques for the first time since it is quite disorganized.

Yes, it is a great course to take and you do learn really useful experimental techniques and knowledge that would be concerned with genetics. The lab course does take a bit amount of class time, although not too much time outside of the scheduled lab time.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. I will say that something which is difficult with lab classes is that they expect you to have pre-existing knowledge/research experience, which feels counterintuitive at the same time because this is a class that is supposed to teach you such lab techniques.
Yes, especially if you are an MCDB major looking to fulfill your lab requirement. Professor Nelson is super knowledgeable and really helpful if you have any questions.
No, the grade basically depends on how the TA is feeling, and you will not know how you are doing all semester. The class is also unorganised, and it is hard to expect what is going to happen.

extras.title: MCDB 342L 01 - Laboratory in Nucleic Acids I
